solution_line_template: Since Jill's basket can hold twice as much as Jack's, and Jack's is capable of holding {jack_basket_capacity} apples in total, this means Jill's basket can hold {jack_basket_capacity}*{jill_capacity_multiplier}=<<{jack_basket_capacity}*{jill_capacity_multiplier}={jill_basket_capacity}>>{jill_basket_capacity} apples in total.

Since Jack has {jack_space_left} less than the maximum amount of apples he can fit in his basket, this means Jack has {jack_basket_capacity}-{jack_space_left}= <<{jack_basket_capacity}-{jack_space_left}={jack_current_apples}>>{jack_current_apples} apples in his basket.

Therefore, Jill's basket can hold {jill_basket_capacity}/{jack_current_apples}= <<{jill_basket_capacity}/{jack_current_apples}={times_jack_apples_fit_in_jill}>>{times_jack_apples_fit_in_jill} times the amount of apples Jack is currently carrying.
